awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Fine-Grained Spectrum Access for Carrier-Aggregation Based Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamic spectrum access brings great benefits for users in overcrowded radio spectrum to opportunistically harvest spectrum resources, which is especially useful for high date rate applications such as video conferencing and multimedia streaming. Since available spectrum may be fragmented, carrier aggregation becomes a critical enabling technique. Many recent and emerging protocols (e.g., 802.11ac WiFi, 802.11af TV whitespace networks, 3GPP LTE unlicensed, and 802.11ay millimeter-wave networks) have been incorporating carrier aggregation mechanisms. However, these mechanisms are still preliminary and heavily rely on conventional MAC/PHY which is designed for nodes sharing the same contiguous channel. As carrier aggregation networks evolve to new generations, three inherent problems will become the fundamental barrier to their efficiency, fairness, and scalability: (i) a transmitter is unable to sense medium state during transmission, (ii) more users and high spectrum dynamics worsen the medium access contention, and (iii) the need of fast spectrum agreement to aggregate multiple fragmented spectrum chunks. 

The objective of this research is to explore general primitives to effectively realize carrier aggregation with three research components: (i) Migrate the spectrum sensing paradigm from "detect and then transmit" to "simultaneously transmit and detect". The end goal is to overcome the efficiency and fairness problems in standard spectrum sensing mechanisms to enable asynchronous, out-of-band OFDM spectrum sensing and multi-antenna based full-duplex sensing. (ii) Address the contention issue in wideband fragmented spectrum sharing with low collision probabilities and low overhead. A spectrum arbitration mechanism is proposed, enabled by a parallel bitwise signaling scheme and a novel compound packet preamble design. (iii) Design a light-weight in-band mechanism that achieves fast synchronization and spectrum agreement, so as to overcome the substantial control channel overhead for spectrum agreement under high spectrum dynamics. The success of the proposed research will enhance radio spectrum sharing, and inspire standardization bodies to incorporate the proposed new protocol primitives for much higher performance. A continuous effort will be made to integrate the proposed research to education program, to mentor undergraduate researchers, and recruit women and minority students.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research is to explore general primitives to effectively aggregate wireless spectrum bands and improve network capacity. Spectrum aggregation is an emerging paradigm of radio resource management, which had initial deployment in recent LTE networks, and is anticipated to dominate emerging network architectures such as LTE-unlicensed and 5G millimeter-wave.  Despite recent progress, the carrier aggregation mechanisms in such standard protocols still heavily rely on conventional protocols that are designed for nodes sharing the same contiguous channel. As carrier aggregation networks evolve to new generations, they need to resolve a few fundamental primitives in order to become efficient, fair, and self-organized. In this project, we explore novel communication mechanisms and network protocols to meet these requirements. More specifically, we investigate novel communication algorithms for simultaneously transmission and spectrum sensing, new network protocols for scalable contention to sporadic (potentially discontinuous) spectrum chunks, and lightweight signaling mechanisms for a pair of transmitter and receiver to reach spectrum agreement. We further explore fundamental primitives such as passive sensing of locations and sensing millimeter-wave link dynamics which can become the building blocks for improving the spectrum efficiency of future generation wireless networks.

The project has led to 4 major milestones:

(1) Sparse channel sensing and out-of-band channel reconstruction. We have explored a sparse out-of-band channel sensing mechanism, that allows a 5 GHz 802.11ac WiFi interface to estimate the channel magnitude/phase of a co-located 60 GHz 802.11ad network interface. This allows the 60 GHz interface to instantaneously predict the best 60 GHz beam and PHY rate setting, with zero probing overhead.  Our experiments demonstrate 25-60% throughput gain over state-of-the-art solutions, while bringing almost 2 orders of magnitude latency improvement when switching across the spectrum bands.

(2) A theoretical framework to analyze the spectrum efficiency gain of full-duplex networks. Our work established a stochastic geometry model to analyze the tradeoff between spectrum efficiency and spatial reuse in full-duplex CSMA networks. The analysis derives closed-form expressions for the full-duplex gain as a function of link distance, interference range, network density, and carrier sensing schemes.  

(3) Chipless RF tags for full-duplex communication and sensing purposes. We designed and implemented  LiveTag, a fully passive, thin metal tag that can be printed on paper-like substrates and attached on objects. The LiveTag is “full-duplex” in nature. The tag is receiving WiFi signals, processing the signals through its resonators, while at the same time transmitting the signals back to the WiFi receiver. The tag can be used not only for touch sensing purposes, but also as a way to identify objects (low-cost, chipless replacement for RFID tags).

(4) Data-driven location sensing: A step towards location-assisted spectrum and interference management. Geo-location information is the key input for many spectrum management systems.  As one starting point to resolve this issue, we have designed and implemented a data-driven deep learning framework to realize environment-independent location sensing, using the wireless channel state information (CSI) as input. The model can be trained in one benchmark environment, but generalized to different environment through a generative model.

(5) Learning-based channel sensing, i.e., using machine learning models to efficiently sense/predict the status of a mmWave link and potential interferences between multiple links. The channel sensing problem is crucial to effective spectrum aggregation, since in mmWave networks, usability of a spectrum depends on not only frequency, but also the potential quality of a directional beam and spatial reuse between multiple coexisting beams. We have explored the learning-based channel sensing to solve two problems. First, we develop a model to discriminate the link outage caused by blockage from mobility respectively, with more than 90% accuracy, which can in turn translate into significant reduction of beam searching overhead. Second, we design an interference prediction framework to manage the inter-beam interference in dense 5G NR networks. Our evaluation demonstrates 15% to 35% of throughput gain over the 5G NR baseline, and only 13% to 17% of performance loss compared with the oracle (computationally intractable) solution.
